<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The fragment OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name) does not invoke any functions from <string.h> and therefore cannot by itself cause accesses beyond the bounds of the object referenced by host_name. Rule 21.17 specifically targets use of the standard string handling functions; a simple null-pointer check is compliant. (Note: if the macro were implemented to dereference host_name or to call string.h functions such as strlen inside the macro, that implementation could violate the rule — but no such behavior is present in the shown fragment.)
